question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
Define a sequence \emph{x}\textsubscript{0}, \emph{x}\textsubscript{1},
... by the initial conditions \emph{x}\textsubscript{0} = \emph{a},
\emph{x}\textsubscript{1} = \emph{b} and \emph{x}\textsubscript{2} =
\emph{c} together with the recursion relation

\[\displaystyle
x_{n+3} = x_{n+2} + x_{n+1} + x_n\]

for \emph{n} = 0, 1, 2, ...

\textbf{(a)} Rewrite this recursion in matrix form
\emph{X\textsubscript{n+1} = AX\textsubscript{n}} for \emph{n} = 0, 1,
2, ... for a sequence \emph{X\textsubscript{n}} of vectors, with an
initial vector \emph{X\textsubscript{0}} and some matrix \emph{A}.
hints:
What will be the (minimal) number of entries in the vector
\emph{X\textsubscript{n}} and what will be the size of the matrix
\emph{A}?

The vector \emph{X\textsubscript{n}} must contain
\emph{x\textsubscript{n+2}}, \emph{x\textsubscript{n+1}} and
\emph{x\textsubscript{n}}, which suggest that \emph{X\textsubscript{n}}
has length 3, and that hence \emph{A} is a \emph{3×3} matrix.

To get to three equations we can always add trivial equations such as
\emph{x\textsubscript{n+2} = x\textsubscript{n+2}}.
